title: Josh Warrington details how cuts affect fighters mental game after Tyson Fury suffers gash
text:
Josh Warrington believes Tyson Fury faces a severe test of his mental strength as he attempts to block out the potential impact of the serious cuts he suffered in his last fight ahead of his eagerly anticipated rematch against Deontay Wilder.

Fury suffered two deep gashes during his win over Otto Wallin last month and there are fears the Gypsy King might not be fully healed by the time he is due to lock horns with Wilder again on 22 February.

Warrington, the IBF featherweight champion and Fury’s stablemate, explained how a cut can represent a serious threat is to a fighter’s focus.

‘Getting cut in a fight is a distraction. You’re worrying about the referee stopping it and your opponent targeting it, but there’s another battle outside the ring,’ he told Metro.co.uk.

Wallin opened up two deep cuts on Fury (Picture: Getty)

‘Once it’s healed, it’ll never be as tough as it once was. You’ll be thinking about that cut in your next fight.’

Fury’s first encounter with Wilder ten months ago went down in the history books as an instant heavyweight classic. The 31-year-old twice peeled himself off the canvas and despite displaying astonishing levels of mental fortitude, he knows he will again be facing boxing’s premier knockout artist in Las Vegas.

WBC champion Wilder can count himself among the heavyweight’s hardest ever punchers and is a unique foe compared to his direct rivals, due to his terrifying one-punch knockout ability.

After twice knocking Fury to the floor, the Bronze Bomber has promised to finish the job in their rematch, with Fury again expected to play the role of the elusive points scorer attempting to evade the poacher once.

Asked how a cut could continue to affect a fighter, Warrington explained it begins to influence your decision-making in the ring.

‘You’ll be a little more cautious in your next fight,’ Warrington said. ‘You might be worried about going on a certain side because you’ll be thinking about a clash of heads or another punch opening it up again.

‘You’ve just got to try and forget about it. Don’t get cut in the first place is my best advice, because it can really mess with you afterwards.’

Fury is expected to be able to return to sparring in mid December and will fill his time between now and then with a stint in the WWE. After two guest appearances on the wrestling platform, Fury announced he would fight his new arch enemy, Braun Strowman, at the end of this month.

And while his wrestling debut may represent a welcome distraction for Fury ahead of his rematch with Wilder, maintaining his focus against the WBC champion could be a far more difficult task than the first time round, given the damage inflicted upon him by Wallin.

Fury is occupying his time with a stint on the WWE (Picture: Getty)

Fury did a superb job of keeping Wilder guessing during their first fight, marrying his renowned elusiveness with an unshakable focus.

But, given he is likely to employ a game plan that has so little margin for error, Warrington explained how easily Fury could fall into the trap of wasting crucial mental energy.

‘Fighters struggle to recover from cuts,’ Warrington admitted.

Wilder and Fury are scheduled to fight again in February (Picture: Getty)

‘Lee Selby is an example of that. He got cut in our fight and he got cut again in the same place in his next fight.

‘It can potentially become a recurring injury that happens every time you fight. Will Tyson be expecting that now?

‘Thinking about it every time he fights… Will he concentrate too much on his defence because he’s afraid he’ll be cut again?

‘Physically a cut obviously affects you in the fight, but I think mentally it can be a big concern afterwards.

‘You only want to be thinking about winning a fight. Any little percentage taken away from your mental game is not good.’
